doc.title: Q4'25 Guidance
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/Burlington Better brands better executionBurlington Better brands better execution_2025-08-29

passages.text: BURL's Q2 print was a strong, high- quality beat on sales and margins driven by a mix shift towards higher- AUR, better brands and continued operating efficiencies from strong execution, giving us even more confidence in the multi- year growth story. We expect another strong result in Q3, and remain bullish both this quarter and longer- term.

Outsized comp driven by AUR as the consumer responded to better branded assortment mix. As we've seen in our last several months of store checks, BURL's branded assortment keeps improving and is now on par with ROST, featuring a growing breadth of mainstream national brands that were inaccessible to BURL even a year ago. As a result, a positive AUR mix shift drove the bulk of the \(5\%\) comp, with traffic being flat (due to weatherdriven traffic declines in May) and pricing only driving a small portion. We expect BURL's strong branded mix to keep driving share gains, likely coming from other value/discount apparel retailers, as well as other off- primers (ROST being the closest competitor).

Mgmt execution drives a steady stream of cost tailwinds. All the \(+120\) bps margin improvement came from underlying improvements in the business model- driving faster turns and lower markdowns in stores, getting more efficient at operating stores and DCs, and lowering shrink. These underlying improvements should continue through the year (and beyond) and Mgmt sound more confident than ever on being able to continue to execute.

Medium- term investment case remains intact. This is not a one- quarter investment story; it is a multi- year self- help story with a \(\sim 25\%\) earnings CAGR. The levers of this multi- year growth pathway remain intact- i.e., store growth, buying capabilities, sourcing efficiencies, and operating leverage and we continue to like the MT investment case.
Outperform, \(\) 365\$
See the Disclosure Appendix of this report for required disclosures, analyst certifications and other

Q1 earnings recap - Burlington: The multi- year growth story continues

Comp grew \(5\%\) in Q2 (vs. \(0 - 2\%\) guide) on top of \(5\%\) comp growth last year, driven entirely by higher ticket \((+MSD\%)\) and new stores comping ahead of the chain and expectations. Q2 started slower in May from cooler weather in the Midwest and Northeast, picking up in June/July as the weather normalized. The strong comp was in spite of softness in certain merchandise categories - e.g., decorative bedding, cookware, toys - as the result of \(145\%\) China tariffs impacting inventory levels for such categories in April and May, which created a drag on Burlington's home business sales trend during the quarter. By demographic, trends were broad- base, with lower- income and Hispanic stores (ex- Puerto Rico and border stores) comping slightly above chain average. Total revenue up \(10\%\) (vs. \(5 - 7\%\) guide), driven by the opening of 23 net new stores, which includes 30 new store openings, 4 relocations, and 3 closings.

Adj. EBIT margin expanded by 90 bps YoY, including \(+120\) bps underlying improvement partially offset by a 30 bps headwind from bankruptcy acquired lease- related expenses. GM expanded 90 bps to \(43.7\%\) driven by 60 bps of merchandise margin improvement, from lower shortage (took physical inventory in Q2) and reduced markdowns (higher inventory turns) more than offsetting a lower markup due to tariffs. GM was also helped by a 30 bps improvement in freight. Adj. SG&A was down 30 bps YoY from comp leverage and cost savings. Adjusted EBIT margin was \(5.6\%\) (vs. \(4.1 - 4.4\%\) guide).
Adj. EPS was \(1.59\) (vs. \(1.08 - 1.18\) guide), inclusive of a 13c impact from bankruptcy acquired lease- related expenses.

Inventory growth was \(+16\%\) , driven by Packaway \((+43\%)\) YoY to \(50\%\) of total vs. \(41\%\) last year) while comparable store inventories were down \(8\%\) . Mgmt noted that merchandise availability in the Off- price channel is very strong right now across the store, and they've been able to take advantage of great deals that they've packed away in reserve, most of which was purchased at pre- tariff prices, which provides their merchants with more flexibility in the chase.

During the quarter, BURL raised \(\) 500m\(in additional term - loan debt to fund the purchase of their highly automated Cactus West Coast distribution center and pay convertible notes that matured in April. Additionally, they upsized and extended their ABL facility in Q2, now a\) \ \(1b\) line maturing in July 2030, which they don't expect to borrow against this year. At the end of Q2, BURL had - \(\) 1.7b\(in total liquidity, consisting of\) \ \(748m\) in cash and \(\) 946m\(in availability on their ABL.\)
Management plans to continue with their buyback program, and this quarter repurchased 102.5k shares in Q2 for \(\) 26m\(, with\) \ \(632m\) remaining on its current share authorization.

Guidance is conservative, with Mgmt not passing on the entire Q2 beat into H2. Burlington raised top end of FY comp and sales guidance, and the range of margin and EPS guidance (details in Exhibit 10) though of the total 42c Q2 beat vs. high- end of guide, only \(\sim 30c\) was passed into the H2 guide. Q3 guidance despite being off to a "solid" start, is also conservative with comp at \(0 - 2\%\) (vs. \(5\%\) Q2) and total sales growth at \(7\%\) (vs. \(10\%\) Q2). FY25 Adjusted EPS guidance including the costs of bankruptcy- related leases acquired is now \(\) 8.80\(\) 20 (vs. \(\) 8.31- 8.91\(prior).
We believe there are a few reasons for this conservatism:

- To demonstrate consistent beats and raises: It seems the biggest reason to continue the pattern of guiding low and beating is to reinforce Burlington's consistency. Burlington doesn't have the same track record of consistent beats and raises compared to its peers TJX and ROST, particularly in recent history with multiple misses and guide-downs in FY22 and FY23. As such, demonstrating consistently strong performance is important to Mgmt. CEO Michael O'Sullivan noted "As is our practice, we will manage the business conservatively and be ready to chase."

- Anticipating tariff headwinds: Mgmt expect a net tariff headwind for the year, despite mitigation efforts that include vendor negotiations, adjusting assortment, driving faster inventory turns, aggressively going after saving across the P&L, and selectively raising prices. In terms of cadence, Mgmt is expecting more pressure on merch margin from tariffs in Q4 vs. Q3, as the share of inventory with the higher tariffs grows within the mix over time.

- Tough Q3 and especially Q4 comps. Last year experienced a strong BTS season, with the first six weeks of the quarter trending \(+6\%\) comp. The trend then decelerated in the back half of the quarter due to unseasonably warm weather, making for an easier compare for this September / October. Q4, similar to the start of Q3, is facing a tough comp of \(6\%\) , with Mgmt noting that, as the result, "upside in Q4 is probably limited."

We model a Q3 beat from stronger comp and margins. While we expect Q3 to start off soft given the tough comp in August 2024 (+6% for first half of Q3 2024), we see opportunity for an acceleration in the back half of the quarter, particularly if weather in late September / October turns out to be more favorable than expected, which is not baked into the current guide. If the weather turns out to be cooler, Mgmt noted their optimism around their terrific outerwear buys and ability to chase, which could drive a better comp result than plan. Given the conservative guide, we model \(4.5\%\) comp (vs. \(0 - 2\%\) guide).

On margins, Mgmt are expecting pressures on gross margin from tariff pressures more than offsetting tailwinds from freight. However, as we've seen from their strong merchandise margin track record YTD, we see opportunity for them to offset the \(\sim 40\) bps tariff headwind (BERNe) through better buying driving lower markdowns and their tariff mitigation strategies - shifting product mix, selectively raising prices, vendor negotiations. On operating expenses, Mgmt expects product sourcing costs to improve, driven by savings initiatives and some comp leverage, and for SG&A to lever on the high- end of comp guide. Altogether, including the impact of bankruptcy leases (11c EPS headwind), we model \(5.9\%\) adj. EBIT margin (vs. \(5 - 5.2\%\) guide) and \(\) 1.81\(EPS (vs.\) \ \(1.39 - 1.49\) ).

We model a Q4 beat vs. the current guide, mostly from margins, and expect a Q4 guidance raise next quarter. Mgmt noted that while the compare last year on comp is tougher for Q4 vs. Q3, there is potential for upside on margins on the high- end (guide: down 10 bps to up 30 bps excluding the lease impact) despite the tariff headwind, driven by product sourcing cost, SG&A leverage, and lapping higher incentive compensation accruals last year. We model comp at the high end of guide (2%). On margins, as new stores have been trending above plan and merch margin has been benefiting from a better buying tailwind, we model \(11.4\%\) adj. EBIT margin (vs. \(10.8 - 11.2\%\) guide) and \(\) 4.76\(EPS (vs.\) \ \(4.22 - 4.52\) ), inclusive of a \(\sim 8c\) EPS headwind from bankruptcy leases.
Looking past this year, the medium- term investment thesis remains attractive, with the multi- year self- help story on track.

Burlington is the least mature, smallest, and lowest margin off- pricer, with the steepest ramp on both top line growth and margin improvement. In late 2023, Mgmt guided for an implied mid- 20s percent five- year EPS CAGR from FY23- 28, with the biggest lever being the store growth strategy, but also improvements in buying capabilities, sourcing efficiencies, operating leverage, and comp sales growth. With \(35\%\) earnings growth in FY24, BURL was already well on its way towards delivering those targets coming into FY25.

We continue to model \(\sim 25\%\) earnings growth over the FY23- 28 period, despite this year's growth estimates coming in below that run- rate \((16\%)\) lapping a very strong 2024. The biggest driver of this multi- year growth pathway will be the store strategy, where Burlington is closing oversized and margin dilutive stores, and opening smaller and more productive stores, thereby boosting comps, GM and SG&A to the tune of \(\sim 13\%\) earnings CAGR in total, i.e. half of Mgmt's medium- term target. With \(+46\) JoAnn stores leases added to the pipeline (to be opened in - Spring'26), plus existing store leases locked in through FY25- 26, this store growth tailwind is locked in for another two years with leases signed until mid- 2027 opening. As the mix of younger, more productive stores in comp base grows, the impact of comp tailwind too will increase over time.
Adding in better buying, operational levers, and buybacks, we expect well above \(20\%\) earnings growth (Exhibit 2).

Despite the uncertainty of FY25, Mgmt's messaging and guidance has clearly shown the improving execution and predictability of the business, especially compared to the guidance misses and cuts two years ago in FY22- 23. Even excluding an expense timing benefit, Q1 delivered a 15c underlying EPS beat from savings already realized across the P&L and Q2 delivered a 40c EPS beat.

In our store checks, we are seeing an increasing array of recognizable national brands including French Connection, Michael Kors, Karl Lagerfeld, Nike, Jordan, Adidas that Burlington would not have had access to \(2+\) years ago. All of this gives us confidence that Burlington is a more predictable, higher quality name vs. 2- 3 years ago.

On margins, Mgmt's commentary that their new stores have been comping "well ahead of original expectations" and seen improvements in major store operating metrics (higher productivity, lower payroll, higher associate engagement scores) provide affirmation that their store strategy is working and the margin tailwinds should continue.
EXHIBIT 1: Burlington posted \(5\%\) comp in Q2
Source: Company disclosures, Bernstein analysis and estimates
EXHIBIT 2: Mgmt's 5-year plan is credible - We model 25% EPS CAGR, half of which is just from opening smaller stores
BURL 2023-28E EPS CAGR Waterfall

On April 1, 2024, Société Générale (SG) and AllianceBernstein, L.P. (AB) completed a transaction that created a new joint venture in which their respective cash equities and research businesses operate in a new business combination. Although their respective ownership percentages in the joint venture differ between North America and the rest of the world, the creation, production and publication of research is handled collaboratively on a global basis across the two research brands, "Bernstein" and "Autonomous". Unless specifically noted otherwise, for purposes of these disclosures, references to Bernstein's "affiliates" relate to both SG and AB and their respective affiliates.
We set a \(\) 365\(price target using a P/E multiple of 24x against our forward FY2027 adjusted EPS estimate of\) \ \(15.06\)
Narrowing of value differential with broader market Quicker than anticipated saturation of Burlington stores in the US Continued increases in US retail and distribution center wages

The Bernstein brand rates stocks based on forecasts of relative performance for the next 12 months versus the S&P 500 for stocks listed on the U.S. and Canadian exchanges, versus the Bloomberg Europe Developed Markets Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index (EDM) for stocks listed on the European exchanges and emerging markets exchanges outside of the Asia Pacific region, versus the Bloomberg Japan Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index USD (JP) for stocks listed on the Japanese exchanges, and versus the Bloomberg Asia ex- Japan Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index (ASIAX) for stocks listed on the Asian (ex- Japan) exchanges - unless otherwise specified.
The Bernstein brand has three categories of ratings:

Outperform: Stock will outpace the market index by more than 15 pp Market- Perform: Stock will perform in line with the market index to within \(+ / - 15\) pp Underperform: Stock will trail the performance of the market index by more than 15 pp

Coverage Suspended: Coverage of a company under the Bernstein research brand has been suspended. Ratings and price targets are suspended temporarily, are no longer current, and should therefore not be relied upon.

Not Rated: A rating assigned when the stock cannot be accurately valued, or the performance of the company accurately predicted, at the present time. The covering analyst may continue to publish research reports on the company to update investors on events and developments.
Not Covered (NC) denotes companies that are not under coverage.

The Autonomous brand rates stocks as indicated below. As our benchmarks we use the Bloomberg Europe 500 Banks And Financial Services Index (BEBANKS) and Bloomberg Europe Dev Mkt Financials Large and Mid Cap Price Ret Index EUR (EDMFI)index for developed European banks and Payments, the Bloomberg Europe 500 Insurance Index (BEINSUR) for European insurers, the S&P 500 and S&P Financials for US banks and Payments coverage, S5LIFE for US Insurance, the S&P Insurance Select Industry (SPSIINS) for US Non-Life Insurers coverage, and the Bloomberg Emerging Markets Financials Large, Mid and Small Cap Price Return Index (EMLSF) for emerging market banks and insurers and Payments. Ratings are stated relative to the sector (not the market).
The Autonomous brand has three categories of ratings:
·Outperform (OP): Stock will outpace the relevant index by more than 10 pp
·Neutral (N): Stock will perform in line with the market index to within +/-10 pp
·Underperform (UP): Stock will trail the performance of the relevant index by more than 10 pp

Coverage Suspended: Coverage of a company under the Bernstein research brand has been suspended. Ratings and price targets are suspended temporarily, are no longer current, and should therefore not be relied upon.

Not Rated: A rating assigned when the stock cannot be accurately valued, or the performance of the company accurately predicted, at the present time. The covering analyst may continue to publish research reports on the company to update investors on events and developments.
Those denoted as 'Feature' (e.g., Feature Outperform FOP, Feature Under Outperform FUP) are our core ideas. Not Covered (NC)denotes companies that are not under coverage.
For both brands, recommendations are based on a 12-month time horizon.
